jstat.data.Document.html:
{{Infobox athlete | name = Matthias Steiner | image = Matthias Steiner (weightlifter) 2.jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = | nationality = {{flag|Austria|name=Austrian}} / {{flag|GER|name=German}} | residence = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|08|25}} | birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{convert|1.83|m|ftin|abbr=on}} (2012) | weight = {{convert|145|kg|lb|abbr=on}} (2012) | website = {{URL|http://www.matthiassteiner.com/}} | country = {{AUT}} (2001–2005)
{{GER}} (2008–) | sport = [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]] | event = +105 kg | club = Chemnitzer AC | turnedpro = 2001 | coach = Frank Mantek, Michael Vater | retired = | coaching = | pb = {{ubl|Snatch: 203 kg (2008)|Clean and jerk: 258 kg (2008)|Total: 461 kg (2008)}} | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport|Men's [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{GER}} }} {{MedalCompetition|[[Weightlifting at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]]}} {{MedalGold | [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing]] | [[Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's +105 kg|+105 kg]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Weightlifting Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[2010 World Weightlifting Championships|2010 Antalya]]| [[2010 World Weightlifting Championships – Men's +105 kg|+105 kg]]}} {{MedalCompetition|European Championships}} {{MedalSilver| [[2008 European Weightlifting Championships|2008 Lignano Sabbiadoro]] | +105 kg}} {{MedalSilver| [[2012 European Weightlifting Championships|2012 Antalya]] | +105 kg}} {{MedalBronze| [[2010 European Weightlifting Championships|2010 Minsk]] | +105 kg}} | show-medals = y }} '''Matthias Steiner''' (born August 25, 1982 in [[Vienna]]) is an [[Austrians|Austrian]]-[[Germany|German]] [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifter]], and [[Weightlifting at the Summer Olympics|Olympic gold medalist]]. As a native [[Austria]]n, he competed for Austria internationally from 1998 to 2005, in European Championships, World Championships, and the [[2004 Summer Olympics]]. From 2002 to 2005 he was four times Austrian National Champion in the +105 kg category, and holds Austrian records in the −105 kg and +105 kg categories. In 2005 Steiner left the Austrian weightlifting federation, and married a German woman. Although his wife died in a car accident, he continued his weightlifting career in Germany, eventually received German citizenship in early 2008, won overall silver at the [[2008 European Weightlifting Championships|2008 European Championships]], and the gold medal at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. ==Early and personal life== Matthias Steiner was born in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]].{{cite news|url= http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/20/sports/olympics/20weightlifting.html|title= Heavy on Emotion|date= 2008-08-20|accessdate= 2008-12-10|publisher= ''[[The New York Times]]''|author=Branch, John}} He hails from Obersulz in [[Lower Austria]], where he attended [[Volksschule]] (primary school), then [[Hauptschule]] (secondary school). Steiner completed an [[apprenticeship]] in [[plumbing]]. He started weightlifting in 1995.{{cite web|title=Matthias Steiner - Das Interview|publisher=diabetes-world.net|url=http://www.diabetes-world.net/Portal-f%C3%BCr-Patienten-und-Interessierte/Lebenssituationen/Prominente/Matthias-Steiner---Das-Interview.htm?ID=3845|accessdate=2008-08-27|language=German}} His father, Friedrich Steiner, a 20-time [[International Weightlifting Federation|IWF]]-Masters World Weightlifting Champion, and also ranks first on the IWF 2008 Hall of Fame Survey of Leading Master Lifters.{{cite news|url= http://www.abendzeitung.de/sport/mehr_sport/75335|title= Matthias Steiner: Seine Geheimnisse|language= German|publisher= ''[[Abendzeitung]]''|date= 2008-12-22|accessdate= 2009-01-08}}{{cite web|url= http://www.iwfmasters.net/hall.htm|title= Hall of Fame Survey (revised 13-Sep-2008)|publisher= IWF-Masters Weightlifting|accessdate= 2009-01-08}} Since an untreated infection{{cite news|title=Steiner: "In Deutschland arbeiten Profis"|url=http://www.laola1.at/129509+M56679564a0f.html|date=2008-08-20|accessdate=2008-08-26|work=LAOLA1.at|language=German}} Steiner suffers from [[diabetes]], diagnosed at his 18th birthday. Before the diagnosis, the first symptom was an intense thirst, then he lost appetite, and {{convert|5|kg|lb}} body weight within three months. He went to the doctor when his sight deteriorated. Despite the diagnosis he followed his dream to become a weightlifter. In 2004, a German woman from [[Zwickau]] in [[Saxony]] had watched Steiner participating in weightlifting contests on TV.{{cite news|title=Matthias Steiner hebt Gold - für Deutschland und seine verstorbene Frau|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/sport/olympia2008/art17786,2596596|accessdate=2008-08-25|publisher= ''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]''|date=2008-08-19|language=German|author= Voigt, Benedikt}} She kept asking the [[Eurosport]] commentators for his email address, until they gave it to her. She contacted Steiner, and he agreed to meet her in Lower Austria.{{cite news|title=461 Kilo - für seine Frau|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/sport/892/306849/text/|accessdate=2008-08-25|publisher= ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]''|date=2008-08-19|language=German|author= Kelnberger, Josef}} They married shortly thereafter and hence he moved to Germany, where he then applied for German citizenship. On July 16, 2007 his wife Susann died in a car accident.{{cite news|title=Die Hantel als Halt|url=http://www.faz.net/s/Rub9CD731D06F17450CB39BE001000DD173/Doc~E579FB66FCBA14722AA498775782AEF85~ATpl~Ecommon~Scontent.html?rss_aktuell| accessdate=2008-08-13|publisher= ''[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]''|author= Simeoni, Evi|date=2007-08-06|language=German}}{{cite news|url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/12/03/ap/europe/main4645629.shtml|title= Suspended sentence for driver who killed wife of German Olympic gold medalist|publisher= [[CBS News]]|agency= [[Associated Press]]|date= 2008-12-03|accessdate= 2008-12-12}} Despite the tragic loss, and after losing {{convert|7|kg|lb}} or {{convert|8|kg|lb}} body weight, he was able to continue his training. In October 2008, Steiner met German TV-newsreader [[Inge Posmyk]]. They married in January 2010.{{cite news|url= http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/leute/0,1518,606209,00.html|title= BALL DES SPORTS: Steiner und Posmyk im Blitzlichtgewitter|publisher= ''[[Der Spiegel]]''|date= 2009-02-07|accessdate= 2009-02-09|language= German}}{{cite news|url= http://www.abendblatt.de/vermischtes/article598328/Inge-Posmyk-und-Matthias-Steiner-Hochzeit-in-Sicht.html|title= Inge Posmyk und Matthias Steiner: Hochzeit in Sicht?|publisher= ''[[Hamburger Abendblatt]]''|date= 2009-02-08|accessdate= 2010-01-30|language= German}}{{cite news|url= http://newsticker.welt.de/?module=dpa&id=23639320|title= Matthias Steiner hat heimlich geheiratet|publisher= ''[[Die Welt]]''|date= 2010-01-23|accessdate= 2010-01-30|language= German}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Weightlifting career== ===1998-2003=== Steiner participated in the 1998 and 1999 European Junior Championships, and the 2000 Junior World Championships. At the 2000 European Junior Championships in [[Rijeka]], [[Croatia]] he came in 8th place in the 94 kg category, with a total of 320 kg (142.5 kg [[Snatch (weightlifting)|snatch]] and 177.5 kg [[clean and jerk]]).{{cite web|title=Steiner Matthias (SAS)|publisher=IAT Weightlifting Database|url=http://www.iat.uni-leipzig.de/datenbanken/dbgwh/daten.php?spid=B65EFE3A3F5547D189EA23095D8AD3C7}} At the 2001 European Junior Championships in [[Kalmar]], [[Sweden]] he won bronze in the -105 kg category, with 360 kg (165 kg and 195 kg). At that time he competed for the AC Woge [[Bregenz]] weightlifting club. At the 2002 European Junior Championships in [[Havířov]], [[Czech Republic]] he won bronze again in the -105 kg category, with 380 kg (172.5 kg and 207.5 kg). Steiner won the Austrian National Championships in the +105 kg category in 2002 with a total of 370 kg, and in 2003 with a total of 390 kg.{{cite web|url= http://www.gewichtheben.net/download/sonstiges/StaatsmeisterSeit1973/Staatsmeister.xls|title= Staatsmeister seit 1973|language= German|accessdate= 2008-12-18|publisher= Austrian Weightlifting Federation|format=xls}} [[File:Matthias Steiner2.jpg|thumb|256px|right|Matthias Steiner 2010]] ===2004=== He won the 2004 Austrian National Championships in the +105 kg category with a total of 400 kg. Steiner continued to increase his performance; at the [[2004 Olympic Games]] in [[Athens]] he competed for Austria, and lifted 405 kg (182.5 kg and 222.5 kg) and went into 7th place in the [[Weightlifting at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's 105 kg|-105 kg category]].{{cite web|title=STEINER Matthias|publisher=International Weightlifting Federation|url=http://www.iwf.net/results/results_athlete_e.php?compid=547}} ===2005=== {{Quote box|quote= ''Im Gewichtheben hat der Trainer so ziemlich den größten Einfluss auf den Ausgang eines Wettkampfs. Darum ist das auch eine so enorm wichtige Person für jeden Athleten.''
In weightlifting, the coach has about the greatest influence on the outcome of a competition. For this reason the coach is such an enormously important person for every athlete.|source= Matthias Steiner, [http://www.laola1.at/129509+M56679564a0f.html Steiner: "In Deutschland arbeiten Profis"]|width= 40%|align= right}} Steiner won the 2005 Austrian National Championships in the +105 kg category with a total of 382.5 kg. Until 2005 he competed regularly in World Championships and European Championships for Austria. In 2005, the Austrian national coach was replaced against Steiners will, which caused tension between Steiner and the Austrian weightlifting federation. He kept the coach as personal coach, who however did not get accredited for the [[2005 European Weightlifting Championships|2005 European Championships]] in [[Sofia]].{{cite news|title=ÖGV und Steiner|url=http://www.laola1.at/129509+M5f50b73d90d.html|date=2008-08-20|accessdate=2008-08-27|work=LAOLA1.at|language=German}} Steiner also could no longer keep his body weight below {{convert|105|kg|lb}}, and bulked up for the +105 kg category. The 2005 European Championships were his first event in the new weight category. At the European Championships, a lot went wrong and Steiner failed three snatch attempts. He had to compete in the B-group, because the European Weightlifting Federation did not accept the announced starting weights. After warming up he disagreed with the national coach concerning the starting weight, and time ran out on the first attempt.{{cite news|title=Matthias Steiner sorgt bei EM für Eklat|url=http://sport.orf.at/ticker/179852.html|accessdate=2008-08-25|work= [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF Sport]]|language=German}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The Austrian national coach, together with other functionaries, accused Steiner of deliberate failure, which Steiner denied. As a consequence, he left the Austrian weightlifting federation. ===2006-2007=== During the three years that Steiner applied for German citizenship, he was not allowed to compete in international competitions. At the [[2007 European Weightlifting Championships|2007 European Championships]] he was co-commentator with [[Marc Huster]] for [[Eurosport]].{{cite web|title=EUROPEAN CHAMPIONSHIPS – REPORT 3: ENGLISH|publisher=ELEIKO Equipment AB, International Weightlifting Agency Berlin (IWA)|url=http://www.eleikosport.se/eng/News_show.asp?NewsPageNumber=256|author= Bürger, Hilmar|accessdate= 2008-12-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Since moving to Germany he competes for the [[Chemnitz]]er AC weightlifting club,{{cite news|title=Gewichtheben: Wenn ein starker Mann in Österreich verkannt wird|url=http://diepresse.com/home/sport/mehrsport/378537/index.do| accessdate=2008-08-13|publisher= ''[[Die Presse]]''|date=2008-04-21|language=German|author= Datler, Markku}} and is their team captain in the German weightlifting league.{{cite web|title=Unser Team - Sportler der Bundesligamannschaft|publisher=Chemnitzer Athleten Club e.V.|url=http://www.chemnitzerac.de/gewichtheben_team.html| accessdate=2008-08-27|language=German}} Steiner trains in the German Federal Weightlifting Center in [[Leimen (Baden)|Leimen]] near [[Heidelberg]], with German national coach [[Frank Mantek]]. [[File:Matthias Steiner.jpg|thumb|256px|right|Matthias Steiner 2010]] ===2008=== Steiner received [[German citizenship]] in early 2008, and started to compete internationally again, for Germany. On January 23, he won the Beijing Pre-Olympic Tournament with a total of 423 kg.{{cite web|title=2008 Invitational Tournament Beijing|url=http://en.beijing2008.cn/goodluckbj/weightlifting2008/s214236903/n214238656.shtml|accessdate=2008-08-26|publisher=The Beijing Organizing Committee for the Games of the XXIX Olympiad}} At the [[2008 European Weightlifting Championships|2008 European Championships]] in [[Lignano Sabbiadoro]], [[Italy]] in the over 105 kg category he was the only lifter to [[snatch (weightlifting)|snatch]] 200 kg, winning gold. In [[clean and jerk]] he won bronze with a personal best of 246 kg. All his six attempts were successful. With a total result of 446 kg he won overall silver behind [[Viktors Ščerbatihs]] from [[Latvia]], who lifted 447 kg.{{cite web|title=STEINER Matthias|publisher=International Weightlifting Federation|url=http://www.iwf.net/results/results_athlete_e.php?compid=1944}} The biggest success of Steiner's career came in August 2008, when he won the gold medal at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. After [[List of World records in weightlifting|World record holder]] [[Hossein Rezazadeh]] had retired in July 2008, the event turned into a close competition between Steiner, [[Evgeny Chigishev]], and the tournament favorite, [[2008 European Weightlifting Championships|European]] and [[2007 World Weightlifting Championships|World champion]] [[Viktors Ščerbatihs]]. During the [[Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's +105 kg|Olympic competition]], Steiner failed in his third [[snatch (weightlifting)|snatch]] attempt, and with 203 kg ranked fourth after the snatch. Ščerbatihs was in position to take the lead in the [[clean and jerk]], but failed in his second attempt. Steiner also failed in his first clean and jerk attempt, and Chigishev took the lead with 250 kg in the clean and jerk. Ščerbatihs failed in his third attempt, which would have forced Steiner to increase his last attempt to 258 kg in order to win gold. With a successful clean and jerk of 258 kg, and a total of 461 kg, Steiner became Olympic gold medalist.{{cite web|url= http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/WL/C73/WLM025000.shtml#WLM025A01|title= Weightlifting Results Men's +105kg|publisher= [[BOCOG]]|accessdate= 2008-12-10}} Steiner stood on the medalists' podium with a photo of his late wife, who would otherwise have accompanied him to the Games.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics/weightlifting/7571099.stm|title=Video - Emotional Steiner lifts weightlifting gold|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=2008-08-19|accessdate=2008-08-20}}{{cite news|url= http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/ronjudd/2008125682_olyjudd20.html|title= A touching Olympic moment that wasn't to be missed|date= 2008-08-20|accessdate= 2008-12-10|publisher= ''[[The Seattle Times]]''|author= Judd, Ron}} ===2009=== In January 2009, Steiner was operated on for an [[inguinal hernia]].{{cite news|url= http://en.olympic.cn/news/sports_news/2009-02-05/1729722.html|title= German weightlifter Matthias Steiner has just undergone surgery|publisher= [[BOCOG]]|date= 2009-02-05|accessdate= 2009-03-12}}{{cite news|url= http://www.focus.de/sport/mehrsport/gewichtheben-wm-olympiasieger-steiner-an-der-leiste-operiert_aid_366327.html|title= Olympiasieger Steiner an der Leiste operiert|publisher= ''[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]]''|date= 2009-01-30|accessdate= 2009-02-09|language= German}} He had to pull out of competing at the 2009 [[Arnold Sports Festival]] in March, nevertheless was part of the German delegation at the event and met with [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]].{{cite news|url= http://en.olympic.cn/news/sports_news/2009-03-05/1750004.html|title= German Weightlifters Up for the Arnold|publisher= [[BOCOG]]|date= 2009-03-05|accessdate= 2009-03-12}}{{cite news|url= http://en.olympic.cn/news/sports_news/2009-03-10/1753395.html|title= Weightlifting: Arnold Schwarzenegger & Steiner Meet|publisher= [[BOCOG]]|date= 2009-03-10|accessdate= 2009-03-12}} At the 2009 German Championships he ranked second in the [[snatch (weightlifting)|snatch]] behind [[Almir Velagic]], and won overall with a total of 430 kg.{{cite news|url= http://www.sueddeutsche.de/sport/889/492248/text/|title= Eisen und andere Lasten|publisher= ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]''|date= 2009-10-25|accessdate= 2010-01-31|language= German}} ===2010=== At the 2010 European Championships he ranked third with a total of 426 kg. ===2012=== In the [[2012 London Olympics]] [[Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's +105 kg|weightlifting competition]] Steiner was injured during the snatch portion of the competition when he attempted to pull 196 kg but was hit in the neck by the barbell. While not seriously hurt, Steiner had to abandon the competition as a result of his injury.[http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/olympics-2012/olympics-2012-defending-champion-matthias-steiner-germany-hit-neck-barbell-unable-continue-article-1.1130834 Defending champion Matthias Steiner of Germany hit in the neck by the barbell, unable to continue] ==Career statistics== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- style="background:#eee;" |'''Date''' |'''Tournament''' |'''Venue''' |'''Weight category''' |'''Snatch''' |'''Rank''' |'''Clean and jerk''' |'''Rank''' |'''Overall''' |'''Rank''' |- | 2001-04-28 | European Championships | Trenčín, Slovakia | -94 kg | 150.0 kg | 15th | 175.0 kg | 15th | 325.0 kg | 16th |- | 2002-04-25 | European Championships | Antalya, Turkey | +105 kg | 172.5 kg | 12th | 207.5 kg | 11th | 380 kg | 11th |- | 2002-11-23 | World Championships | Warsaw, Poland | -105 kg | 180.0 kg | 12th | 215.0 kg | 12th | 395.0 kg | 12th |- | 2003-04-18 | European Championships | Loutraki, Greece | -105 kg | 180.0 kg | 8th | 212.5 kg | 9th | 392.5 kg | 8th |- | 2003-11-17 | World Championships | [[2003 World Weightlifting Championships|Vancouver, Canada]] | -105 kg | 182.5 kg | 9th | 220.0 kg | 6th | 402.5 kg | 7th |- | 2004-04-24 | European Championships | Kiev, Ukraine | -105 kg | 180.0 kg | 10th | 225.0 kg | 5th | 405.0 kg | 7th |- | 2004-08-15 | Olympic Games | [[Weightlifting at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's 105 kg|Athens, Greece]] | -105 kg | 182.5 kg | - | 222.5 kg | - | 405.0 kg | 7th |- | 2005-04-22 | European Championships | Sofia, Bulgaria | +105 kg | - | - | - | - | - | DNF |- | 2008-04-14 | European Championships | [[2008 European Weightlifting Championships|Lignano S., Italy]] | +105 kg | 200.0 kg | 1st | 246.0 kg | 3rd | 446.0 kg | 2nd |- | 2008-08-19 | Olympic Games | [[Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's +105 kg|Beijing, China]] | +105 kg | 203.0 kg | - | 258.0 kg | - | 461.0 kg | 1st |- | 2010-04-11 | European Championships | [[2010 European Weightlifting Championships|Minsk, Belarus]] | +105 kg | 190.0 kg | 4th | 236.0 kg | 2nd | 426.0 kg | 3rd |} === National championships === {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- style="background:#eee;" |'''Year''' |'''Country''' |'''Weight category''' |'''Snatch''' |'''Rank''' |'''Clean and jerk''' |'''Rank''' |'''Overall''' |'''Rank''' |- | 2002 | Austria | +105 kg | 167.5 kg | 1st | 202.5 kg | 1st | 370.0 kg | 1st |- | 2003 | Austria | +105 kg | 175.0 kg | 1st | 215.0 kg | 1st | 390.0 kg | 1st |- | 2004 | Austria | +105 kg | 177.5 kg | 1st | 222.5 kg | 1st | 400.0 kg | 1st |- | 2005 | Austria | +105 kg | 172.5 kg | 1st | 210.0 kg | 1st | 382.5 kg | 1st |- | 2009 | Germany | +105 kg | 190.0 kg | 2nd | 240.0 kg | 1st | 430.0 kg | 1st |} === Personal bests === * [[Snatch (weightlifting)|Snatch]]: {{convert|203|kg|lb|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} * [[Clean and jerk]]: {{convert|258|kg|lb|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} * Combined: {{convert|461|kg|lb|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} Steiner holds Austrian records in the -105 kg and +105 kg categories.{{cite web|url= http://www.gewichtheben.net/rekorde/rekorde_oe_allgkl.htm|title= Rekorde: Allgemeine Klasse Männer|language= German|accessdate= 2008-12-18|publisher= Austrian Weightlifting Federation}} == Sponsorships == In 2008, Steiner signed a four year contract with marketing company "movie & more" in [[Cologne]].{{cite web|url= http://www.movie-and-more.de/News/Matthias_Steiner.html|title= Olympia-Sieger Matthias Steiner bei movie & more|accessdate= 2008-12-06|language= German}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Previously, he was supported by [[Stiftung Deutsche Sporthilfe]] and his weightlifting club ''Chemnitzer AC''. The [[Bundeswehr]], while supporting other German weightlifters, did not admit Steiner because of his diabetes.{{cite web|url= http://www.presseportal.de/pm/51413/1260356/stiftung_deutsche_sporthilfe|title= Sportler des Monats: Goldmedaillengewinner im Gewichtheben Matthias Steiner im Gespräch|publisher= ''Stiftung Deutsche Sporthilfe''|date= 2008-09-08|accessdate= 2008-12-06|language= German}} == Media == On August 20, 2008, the day after he won the Olympic gold medal, Steiner featured on the cover of [[China Daily]]'s ''Olympian'', titled "Supersteiner".{{cite web|url= http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/olympian/2008-08/20/index1.html|title= OLYMPIAN - Wednesday August 20, 2008|publisher= ''[[China Daily]]''|date= 2008-08-20|accessdate= 2008-12-12}}{{cite news|url= http://www.fr-online.de/in_und_ausland/sport/olympia_2008/sportarten/gewichtheben/1579809_Steiners-Schicksal-ruehrt-Millionen.html|title= Steiners Schicksal rührt Millionen|publisher= ''[[Frankfurter Rundschau]]''|date= 2008-08-20|accessdate= 2008-12-12|language=German|agency= [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} === TV appearances === Apart from [[broadcasting of sports events|sports events]], where he participated in or commented on weightlifting competitions, Steiner also appeared on a number of [[talk show]]s and [[game show]]s in Germany and Austria, including ''[[Wetten, dass..?]]'' and ''[[Die Millionenshow]]'' (Austrian ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?'', Celebrity Special Edition).{{IMDb name|id=3124819|name=Matthias Steiner}} ==Awards== * ''Goldenes Ehrenzeichen für Verdienste um die Republik Österreich'' (Austria){{cite web|url= http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung.php?schluessel=OTS_20081003_OTS0204&ch=politik|title= Sportstaatssekretär Lopatka: Nach Gold in Peking Goldenes Ehrenzeichen für Matthias Steiner|publisher= Bundespressedienst|date= 2008-10-03|accessdate= 2008-12-03|language= German}}{{cite news|url= http://en.olympic.cn/news/sports_news/2009-03-04/1749269.html|title= Austria's homage to German Olympic
